name: Gene Louis Kim
content: Gene Louis Kim Gene Louis Kim Assistant Professor I am an Assistant Professor at the University of South Florida's Department of Computer Science and Engineering and Director of the Language GRASP Lab. I received by doctorate at the University of Rochester, advised by Len Schubert. My research interests are in the intersection of natural language processing, computer reasoning, and computational linguistics. I create algorithms that model formal representations of natural language meaning and structured information to enable computers to interact with language in a generalizable manner. My long term research goal is to enable computers to robustly understand and use natural language in arbitrary settings. Email: genekim AT usf DOT edu Office: Engineering Building II 376 CV Graduate Students Mahammad Kamruzzaman Maneesh Reddy Chamakura Abdullah Al Monsur Sai Durga Shashidhar Pothukuchi Undergraduate Research Assistants Jeremy Rutter Justin Delgado Suryakanth Prasad Gottipati Omar Abdulrahman Adam Brohl (@ Knox College) Kenneth Verzyl Fiorella Andrea Ratti Tamayo Jason Rudinsky Shrabon Das Taylor Tiedge Online Resources ULF Website This is the general project website for the ULF project. It holds a collection of blog posts that describe ULF in more detail than possible in publications or focused documents. It also links to resources used by the project, such as annotation guidelines, the annotator, and code. ULF and Inference Annotators Annotators for my research project on annotating and demonstrating the inference capabilities of underspecified episodic logic. If you're interested in getting involved please let me know! I'm always looking for more collaborators on this project. Related resources: ULF Annotation Guidelines (Steel Bank Common) Lisp Highlights This documents highlights aspects of Steel Bank Common Lisp that are important for getting started as a beginner. It covers important functions to know, some weird aspects of Lisp, minimal debugging tips, and some exercises to get comfortable with Lisp programming.
